mn82:42.17: They take out the body wrapped in a shroud,
mn82:42.18: heap up a pyre, and burn it there.
mn82:42.19: It’s poked with stakes while being burnt,
mn82:42.20: in just a single cloth, all wealth gone.
mn82:42.22: can’t help you when you’re dying.
mn82:42.24: while beings fare on according to their deeds.
mn82:42.25: Riches don’t follow you when you die;
mn82:42.26: nor do children, wife, wealth, nor kingdom.
mn82:42.28: nor does wealth banish old age;
mn82:42.29: for the attentive say this life is short,
mn82:42.31: The rich and the poor feel its touch;
mn82:42.32: the fool and the attentive one feel it too.
mn82:42.33: But the fool lies stricken by their own folly,
mn82:42.34: while the attentive one does not tremble at the touch.
mn82:42.35: Therefore wisdom’s much better than wealth,
mn82:42.36: since by wisdom <j>you reach consummation in this life.
mn82:42.37: But if because of delusion <j>you don’t reach consummation,
mn82:42.38: you’ll do evil deeds in life after life.
mn82:42.39: One who enters a womb and the world beyond,
mn82:42.40: will transmigrate from one life to the next.
mn82:42.41: While someone of little wisdom, <j>placing faith in them,
mn82:42.42: also enters a womb and the world beyond.
mn82:42.43: As a bandit caught in a window
mn82:42.44: is punished for his own bad deeds;
mn82:42.45: so after departing, in the world beyond,
mn82:42.46: people are punished for their own bad deeds.
mn82:42.47: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful;
mn82:42.48: appearing in disguise they disturb the mind.
mn82:42.51: As fruit falls from a tree, so the sons of Manu fall,
mn82:42.52: young and old, when the body breaks up.
mn82:42.53: Seeing this, too, I went forth, O King;
mn82:42.54: the ascetic life is unfailingly better.”
